headline: Israel’s Encouraging Turn Toward Ukraine
author: Michael Oren
sentences:
Explaining the vote, Israeli Foreign Minister Yair Lapid stated that “intentionally harming a civilian population is a war crime and I strongly condemn it.” Moscow’s Foreign Ministry responded with a blistering censure of his “anti-Russian attack.”

After refusing to back a United Nations Security Council condemnation of Russia for the invasion, Israel supported a similar General Assembly resolution denouncing Russia’s aggression.
One of Jerusalem’s most fervent supporters, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R., S.C.), was “very disappointed” by Israel’s refusal to sell the Iron Dome antirocket system to Ukraine.
Israel has been condemned, both by its opponents and some of its friends, for being too neutral toward Russia after its invasion of Ukraine.
I too was critical at first, publicly warning of the dangers, both moral and diplomatic, of an evenhanded Israeli approach to the war.
Critics belittle Jerusalem’s mediation efforts, which, they claim, are contrary to U.S. and Ukrainian interests.
More recently, the Jewish state has called for Russia’s ouster from the U.N. Human Rights Council.
McMaster said “Israelis ought to be embarrassed” by their government’s lack of support for Kyiv.
But Israel has since turned to take a principled stand for Ukraine.
